28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.description: Grow biofuels, burn them for energy, then capture and store the CO2 emitted.
28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.name: BECCS
28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.notes:
The 2.5% figure actually includes geothermal, tidal/wave, as well as biomass...others seem marginal enough that we can just assign it all to biomass.

The book has 0.3W/m2 for liquid biofuels (ethanol/biodiesel) and 0.9W/m2 for solid biofuels (wood) and gaseous biofuels (phytomass). We'll assume the latter for all biomass electricity, so that's 7.884kWh/m2 or 0.1268m2/kWh

https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives a water footprint of 48,000-500,000 m3/TJ net energy for firewood; going to be very crude and assume that all BECCS are using wood pellets and that firewood is equivalent to that. So say 274,000 m3/TJ or 986.4L/kWh

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives the following EROIs:
- Ethanol (sugarcane): 0.8 to 10
- Corn-based ethanol: 0.8 to 1.6
- Biodiesel: 1.3
Let's say 5.4, or 0.185kWh/kWh, split between electricity and fuel.

This plant in the UK is supposed to capture 350tCO2/year while generating 300MWh/year: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/911268/potential-of-bioenergy-with-carbon-capture.pdf (from 1/2020) using 100% wood pellets (other figures I've found were for biomass/coal co-firing plants). This would be about 1166.67g CO2 sequestered/kWh

As for N2O emissions, assuming the biomass is grown similar to industrial agriculture, we have 0.0001473g N2O for our industrial ag crop process, and with the conversion of 860.421kcals/kWh we get about 0.12674g N2O/kWh from fertilizer application. The problem with this conversion is that with our industrial ag crop process we are only counting human-consumed kcals; in practice inedible parts of the plants are also burned for energy. So this figure is almost certainly an overestimate, maybe just hand wave and cut it into half to 0.06337gN2O/kWh.

b30c7bef-f826-4a6b-a76d-b8412480bb9e.name: Nuclear Fusion
b30c7bef-f826-4a6b-a76d-b8412480bb9e.notes:
Per: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3263804/
- A fusion power plant would occupy roughly the same land as a fission plant
- No CO2 or other pollution 
- Interestingly, it uses lithium as its main feedstock: "One kilogram of natural lithium yields about 3×10^13 J or equivalent to 9×10^5 l of petrol." So about 8333330 kWh/kg or 0.00012g/kWh

Per land use, we have 0.000119m3/kWh for nuclear fission, so just assume the same esp. if that figure is mostly for feedstock extraction (uranium/lithium)

Jiang, Songyan; Zhang, Ling; Li, Fengying; Hua, Hui; Liu, Xin; Yuan, Zengwei; Wu, Huijun (2020). Environmental impacts of lithium production showing the importance of primary data of upstream process in life-cycle assessment. Journal of Environmental Management, 262(), 110253–. doi:10.1016/j.jenvman.2020.110253  
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479720301882
LCA of lithium carbonate production (lithium makes up ~18.8% of lithium carbonate by mass), comparing rock-based extraction vs brine-based extraction. Brine-based is way less intense, assuming we use that.
Per 1 kg of lithium carbonate:
- water use: 7.73e2 kg = 7.73e2 L = about 0.0000928L/kWh
- global warming potential: 0.329 kg CO2eq = about 0.0000395 g CO2eq/kWh

For energy use they only have numbers for rock-based lithium:
- Electricity: 3.38kWh/kg = about 0.00000046 kWh/kWh
Natural gas is also used (1.36m3/kg)

4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.description: Meat cultivated in a lab setting
4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.name: Cellular Meat
4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.notes:
takes significant scientific capital

seems like lab-meat ain't coming any time soon:

https://thecounter.org/lab-grown-cultivated-meat-cost-at-scale/

A friend of mine who work on the topic (Jan Dutkiewicz) says that lab meat might be possible at scale by 2040 or 2050, but that's a big if

makes vegan or vegetarian mandate easier

Probably too little too late

Maybe it will cut into meat consumption by 20% or so, but will not replace meat unless there is a mandate

https://cedelft.eu/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2021/04/CE_Delft_190107_LCA_of_cultivated_meat_Def.pdf
Energy use: 147-264MJ/kg (~205.5MJ/kg = 57.1kWh/kg)
Land use: 1.8m2/kg
Water use: 42-56litre/kg (~49litre/kg)
> The main driver for the carbon footprint in the 
conventional energy scenario is electricity use during production, followed by the 
production of medium ingredients. A significant reduction in carbon footprint can be 
achieved by decarbonising the energy mix. In the (upstream) production of medium, 
reductions that can be achieved by decarbonisation are smaller because a part of the 
carbon footprint there is caused by the agricultural production of the feedstock and 
chemicals used during production of the medium ingredients, which rely on heavy industrial 
processes, that are harder to decarbonise. Scaffolds (assumed in this study to be in the 
form of a hydrogel), equipment, wastewater treatment and HVAC of the facility make up a 
relatively minor part of the carbon footprint (total of < 2%).
So aside from energy, the other main contributor to GHG emissions (more significant under the renewable scenario) is the medium's production: roughly 1.25kgCO2eq/kg
Conversion from kg to kcals:
Beef sausage is about ~3400kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/746779/nutrients)
Pork sausage is about ~3200kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/746780/nutrients)
Chicken is about ~1500kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/331897/nutrients)
So say 2700kcals/kg on average

These figures then are:
Energy use: 57.1kWh/kg = 0.2kWh/kcal
Land use: 1.8m2/kg = 0.00067m2/kcal
Water use: 49litre/kg = 0.018litre/kcal
Non-energy GHG emissions: 1.25kgCO2eq/kg = 1250.0gCO2eq/kg = 0.463gCO2eq/kcal

e07bcc6c-cb84-4797-b480-560152091526.notes:
"Each abortion reduces total fertility by less than one birth because it results in a shorter period of gestation and more rapid return of fertility than a full term pregnancy. The net effect is estimated to be 0.4 births averted per abortion in the absence of contraceptive use. Higher rates of contraceptive use lead to larger effects of abortion on fertility since the risk of conception is lower than without contraception." https://bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12889-017-4740-7

Not sure if I understood that paper correctly, but based on Fig. 4 it seems like the effect of wider contraceptive availability is estimated to lead to something like a 30-40% in births

lines.speaker: The Agronomist

lines.speaker: The Agronomist
lines.text: Some good news! Because the world's cities are free of cars, residents have reclaimed a great deal of space once taken up by roads.

lines.speaker: The Agronomist
lines.text: With all the experience gained from trends in urban gardening, urban residents have converted this reclaimed land to productive urban farming plots.

lines.speaker: The Agronomist
lines.text: This will take some load off other parts of the food system and make these communities more resilient to food supply problems.

11ace984-b29b-4043-8fd7-cf712f3de6f1.name: Urban Farming
11ace984-b29b-4043-8fd7-cf712f3de6f1.notes:
This article cites an estimate that 15-20% of global food demand can be met with urban agriculture: https://civileats.com/2019/02/14/how-urban-agriculture-can-improve-food-security/
But I haven't found any other estimates or more recent ones (the cited one is from 2001, and the citation doesn't link to the actual claim...). A more conservative estimate of 10% of food demand through UA feels reasonable.

387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.description: Install DAC units to take CO2 out of the atmosphere.
387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.name: Direct Air Capture
387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.notes:
to sequester 30 gt C a year by 2100, DACCS would require massive amount of energy, up to 300 EJ. total world energy production in 2020 was 550 EJ. Study includes charts comparing water, land, and energy use by DACCS, BECCS, and afforestation. authors expect it to be scaled up 1.5gt C per year

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-019-10842-5

From that paper:
For 30 GtCO2/year it requires something like 250EJ/yr, about 500Gt H2O/yr = 500km3/yr, and negligible land use. So every 1.5GtCO2/year requires 12.5EJ/yr (~3.47e12 kWh/year, rounded to 3.5e12kWh/year) and 25km3 water/yr
So if it can scale up 1.5GtCO2/year we can make this a 5-year project with upgrades.

reduces steel demand significantly, but increases demand on tree plantations. Not great if you are doing BECCS, but easy if you have banned meat


great study:
Churkina, Galina, Alan Organschi, Christopher PO Reyer, Andrew Ruff, Kira Vinke, Zhu Liu, Barbara K. Reck, T. E. Graedel, and Hans Joachim Schellnhuber. "Buildings as a global carbon sink." Nature Sustainability 3, no. 4 (2020): 269-276.

Churkina basically has four scenarios, including one with 90% of buildings made of wood rather than 99.5% steel and concrete. Significant co2 sequestration (2-20 Gt C) but needs about 40% of current wood production.

dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.description: Search for safer and more energy-efficient refrigerants
dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.name: Alternative Refrigerants
dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.notes:
We aren't modeling HFCs specifically (though hector supports it)

This report suggests that "Reductions of between 210 and 460 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent emissions can be delivered over the next four decades through actions to improve the cooling industry’s energy efficiency together with the transition to climate-friendly refrigerants"
https://www.iea.org/news/climate-friendly-cooling-could-cut-years-of-greenhouse-gas-emissions-and-save-trillions-of-dollars
https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/71c8db7e-1137-41ef-99c3-8f2c8d3a5d86/Cooling_Emissions_and_Policy_Synthesis_Report.pdf

So let's say that's like 8.375GtCO2eq annual emissions reduction
This is using best available technology in 2018; 3/4 of the emissions reduction is from energy efficient improvements, "equivalent to an average 40% efficiency improvement."

HFC-134a is the most common refrigerant with a GWP of 1360
Global AC energy demand in 2016 was 2,000TWh; total of all cooling equipment in 2018 estimated to be 3900TWh

Since we aren't modeling HFCs (as far as I can tell they are relatively insignificant in overall CO2eq emissions) we can just focus on the energy use of cooling, especially if energy efficiency makes up the bulk of those emissions improvements.

We're modeling "buildings" as one sector, so we don't have specifics on cooling energy usage. This is for NYC: https://qsel.columbia.edu/nycenergy/about.html but shows that cooling is a relatively small part of energy use. I imagine it's much higher for warmer climates.

For the US as a whole, https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=1174&t=1
> The residential sector’s electricity use for cooling was about 236 billion kWh in 2020, which was equal to about 16% of total residential sector electricity consumption and 6% of total U.S. electricity consumption.
>
> The commercial sector, which includes commercial and institutional buildings, used about 155 billion kWh for cooling in 2020, which was equal to about 12% of total commercial sector electricity consumption and 4% of total U.S. electricity consumption.

So making the really crude assumption that the US covers a wide enough range of climates that we can take these numbers to be representative of the whole world, let's say 14% of building electricity use in general is from cooling, and assume this research gives us 40% energy use efficiency on cooling, then this is roughly gives us an overall electricity use modifier of 0.96

cd261811-0499-4383-9fe5-b25587a0da43.notes:
Catch-all for industries not otherwise specified or for resource/byproducts that weren't disaggregated into specific industries (and for our purposes don't need to be). For example, we don't have water usage for each industry but we do have aggregate industrial water usage.

Because settlement and infrastructure land use is only 1% of total habitable land use (versus 50% for agriculture), see https://ourworldindata.org/land-use, assume land use for these industries is basically negligible.

A note on "low-income-capita" (LIC)--these are the per-capita rates for a person in a low-income country. If the world was just low-income people but had equivalent total of material footprint, the population would be 37 billion. A different LIC scaling rate is calculated for different resources--all industries are scale based on material footprint, but household water consumption, electricity, fuel, and plant and animal calories have different scaling rates (see `Consts`).

ca2a45eb-1186-45b6-b7cf-8f29af4bed6a.name: Petroleum Power Generation
ca2a45eb-1186-45b6-b7cf-8f29af4bed6a.notes:
Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
650 W/m2 per year = 5694kWh/m2 = 0.0001756m2/kWh

For CO2 emissions, the book has 8.8kg CO2/yr/W which is about 1005gCO2/kWh

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Petroleum liquids: 0.08 gal/kWh = 0.3636872 litres/kWh

From https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 we get a mean of about 30EROI for oil, or about 0.03333kWh/kWh, which we'll split between electricity and fuel 50/50.

From https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf we have the following water footprints:
- Conventional oil: 214-1190m3/TJ net energy
- Unconventional oil (oil sand): 419-1340m3/TJ net energy
- Unconventional oil (oil shale): 316-1830m3/TJ net energy

These are all roughly in similar ranges, so we'll do 1022m3/TJ overall, or about 3.68L/kWh

https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from
This also attributes 3.9% of 2016 emissions (49.4GtCO2eq) to fugitive methane emissions from gas and oil production, so about 1.93GtCO2eq or about 0.0535Gt CH4 using CH4 GWP of 36.

Per https://enerji.mmo.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Key_World_energy-statistics-2018.pdf oil made up 31.9% of total global energy (total is 13,761Mtoe, or 1.6e14kWh), so oil made up 5.104e13 kWh. Natural gas made up 22.1% of energy, so about 3.536e13 kWh. Assuming that these each leak the same amount of CH4, we can assign about 59.07% of these emissions to oil production, giving us 0.0316Gt CH4 or about 0.6191g CH4/kWh.

874248df-119a-4308-be03-5ac179942027.name: Coal Power Generation
874248df-119a-4308-be03-5ac179942027.notes:
Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
1,000 W/m2 per year = 8760kWh/m2 = 0.000114m2/kWh

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Coal: 1.13 lbs/kWh = 0.000512559 tonnes/kWh = 512.559 g/kWh

For CO2 emissions, this https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56487.pdf says about 1,000gCO2eq/kWh. The book has 8.5kg CO2/yr/W which is about 970gCO2/kWh

For CH4 emissions, https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from says in 2016 1.9% of 49.4GtCO2eq was due to methane leakages from coal mining, which is 0.9386GtCO2eq or 0.026GtCH4 with a GWP of 36. According to IEA's Key World Energy Statistics 2018 (https://enerji.mmo.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Key_World_energy-statistics-2018.pdf) in 2016 coal made up 28.1% of the world's primary energy supply of 13,647Mtoe (1.6e14kWh), so coal was 4.496e13 kWh, so about 0.57829g CH4/kWh

For EROI https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 27-80 with a mean of 56.4 over the values provided, so about 0.0177kWh/kWh. Again, splitting half/half between fuel/electricity.

For water, https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf separates lignite from coal; we'll just use coal here. It gives 79-2100 m3/TJ net energy, we'll say ~1090m3/TJ, or 0.00392m3/kWh

991816ff-14f8-4751-b2ae-08c6ceef88a5.name: Natural Gas Power Generation
991816ff-14f8-4751-b2ae-08c6ceef88a5.notes:
Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
4500 W/m2 per year = 39420 kWh/m2
And for emissions: 3.6 kg CO2/W/yr 3.6kg CO2/8.76kWh = 410.9589g CO2/kWh
Which is roughly the figure here: https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=74&t=11 (412.7691g CO2/kWh)

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Natural gas: 7.43 ft3/kWh = 210.3942 litres/kWh

For CH4 emissions: https://www.epa.gov/natural-gas-star-program/estimates-methane-emissions-segment-united-states
Which gives (for 2019):
- 12MMTCO2eq to gas processing
- 37MMTCO2eq to gas transmission and storage
- 14MMTCO2eq to gas distribution
- 94.56MMTCO2eq to gas production
For a total of: 157.56MMTCO2eq = 4.377e12 gCH4 using CH4 GWP of 36
For 2020, US natural gas energy production was 1,617 billion kWh (https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=427&t=3) which gives 2.7g CH4/kWh

https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from
This also attributes 3.9% of 2016 emissions (49.4GtCO2eq) to fugitive methane emissions from gas and oil production.

For EROI this https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 20-67, with a mean of 37.75 over the values provided. That's about 0.0265kWh/kWh, which I'll just split evenly b/w fuel and electricity.

For water use this https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives a range of 76-1240m3/TJ net energy. That's a huge range but we'll just say 658m3/TJ or 2.3688L/kWh

1af360c3-5f08-4fae-9ea1-8264d4c1fc5a.name: Nuclear Power
1af360c3-5f08-4fae-9ea1-8264d4c1fc5a.notes:
Per this article from the Rocky Mountain Institute: https://rmi.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/2011-07_RenewableEnergysFootprintMyth.pdf, which cites https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1364032108001354 (V. Fthenakis & H.C. Kim, Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews 13:1465–1474 (2009)):

119 m2/GWh for nuclear (in the US) so 0.000119m2/kWh
I believe this accounts for extraction etc

https://css.umich.edu/factsheets/nuclear-energy-factsheet
> -  A uranium fuel pellet (~1/2 in. height and diameter) contains the energy equivalent of one ton of coal or 149 gallons of oil.10 Typical reactors hold 18 million pellets.6
> - Each kWh of nuclear electricity requires 0.1-0.3 kWh of life cycle energy inputs.20 [say 0.2 and split 50/50 between electricity and fuel]
> - The life cycle GHG intensity of nuclear power is estimated to be 34-60 gCO2e/kWh—far below baseload sources such as coal (1,001 gCO2e/kWh).21,22 [say 47gCO2e/kWh]
> - Nuclear power plants consume 270-670 gallons of water/MWh, depending on operating efficiency and site conditions.23 [say 470 gallons/MWh, or 2136.66L/MWh]

For energy inputs, this also gives a range of 5-15 EROI for nuclear, so 0.2 to 0.06kWh/kWh.

https://whatisnuclear.com/energy-density.html
> A single fuel pellet may weigh about 10 grams so it contains 40,000 MJ in a typical reactor [LWR] and 800,000 MJ in a breeder reactor.
So about 10g/11111.111kWh = 0.0009g/kWh

719d08f4-8d02-41a3-9f0f-57bfd936ea9a.notes:

https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives us a massive range for water usage, 300-850,000m3/TJ net energy...we'll say 425,150m3/TJ or 1530.5L/kWh

http://www.ipcc-wg3.de/report/IPCC_SRREN_Ch05.pdf gives a range of 4-14gCO2eq/kWh, so we'll say 9gCO2eq/kWh

For land use, https://www.researchgate.net/publication/350358598_Land-use_intensity_of_electricity_production_and_tomorrow%27s_energy_landscape gives a median of 650ha/TWh/y or 0.0065m2/kWh

7fa623e7-264f-42a8-92b5-6e621539cb03.name: Terrestrial Wind Power
7fa623e7-264f-42a8-92b5-6e621539cb03.notes:
This % is all wind power--what % is offshore?

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives an EROI of 18, so 0.0556kWh/kWh

For water, https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives 0.2-12m3/TJ net energy, we'll say 6.1m3/TJ, or 0.022L/kWh

https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/57131.pdf gives ~10gCO2eq/kWh

0e7c8ae6-e36f-4167-b880-cc7ff3605a8d.name: Solar PV
0e7c8ae6-e36f-4167-b880-cc7ff3605a8d.notes:
Per the book, assume land use of 10W/m2 (per year) so about 0.0114m3/kWh.

The book assumes 0 emissions for solar but we can use this figure from https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56487.pdf, of ~40g CO2eq/kWh

Mekonnen, M. M., Gerbens-Leenes, P. W., & Hoekstra, A. Y. (2015). The consumptive water footprint of electricity and heat: a global assessment. Environmental Science: Water Research & Technology, 1(3), 285-297.
https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf
For PV has a range of 6.4-303 m3 per TJ of net energy produced, so let's say 154.7 m3/TJ, which is about 0.557L/kWh.

For energy inputs, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 6-12 for PV, that range is from 2009 and presumably solar PV production has improved a lot since then, so maybe say the higher end of that range (12). Which means about 0.083kWh/kWh

For biodiversity pressure, assume it's all through land use.

For feedstock, we assume that it's all captured through land use (of course would vary according to sun/sky conditions/solar irradiance but I believe that land use number encapsulates an average of those)

Energy use:

> For example, strawberries grown on a conventional farm in Chile require 0.4524 kiloWatt hours (kWh) of electricity per square metre per year (sq.m/year). Whereas strawberries grown on a vertical farm in Russia require over 3,000% more energy at 1,404 kWh/sq.m/year. https://www.rsis.edu.sg/rsis-publication/nts/vertical-farms-are-they-sustainable/

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Hello, welcome to the Gosplant planning application. You can call me Gossy.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Following the recent revolution, you've been elected as the lead planner and tasked with the responsibility of guiding us all into a better future.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: This planning application lets you make your plan. You can set research priorities, initiate large-scale projects, implement policies, or ban certain production processes.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: But you don't have complete authority to make decisions unilaterally. You'll need to spend political capital if you want something to happen.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: The people have the right to recall you from your position if they are unsatisfied with your decisions.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: When the people are happy with your work, you'll gain political capital. This lets you expand what you can do as a planner.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: But if you run out of political capital, you will be recalled and your term will end.

dialogue.speaker: Gossy
dialogue.text: Hello, welcome to the Gosplant planning application. You can call me Gossy.

lines.speaker: The Climatologist
lines.text: Warmer temperatures are bringing more severe flooding events.

lines.speaker: The Climatologist
lines.text: Flooding events are becoming much more extreme.

lines.speaker: The Climatologist
lines.text: Wildfires are becoming more severe on average.

lines.speaker: The Climatologist
lines.text: Wildfires are regularly becoming massive...the dense smoke

lines.speaker: The Health Czar
lines.text: Heatwaves are growing more severe

lines.speaker: The Agronomist
lines.text: Famine! Crop failures and inadequate food production is leaving people hungry.

lines.speaker: The Health Czar
lines.text: A major zoonotic disease outbreak from a high intensity livestock operation

lines.speaker: The Meat Militia
lines.text: We will begin attacking plant-based food production

lines.speaker: The Green Meanies
lines.text: Planner! Now is our time to act! We will strike at the lifeblood of technological civilization: energy.

lines.speaker: The Wretched
lines.text: Planner! Your eugenicist policies can't be allowed to continue any longer.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: We'll need help from various technologies and techniques--not only new ones, but also the re-introduction and refinement of older ones too.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Here you can turn political capital into scientific capital, and use that to set research priorities.

0d080b15-013d-410e-a12c-43dfc2011cf9.name: The Malthusians

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Wide-ranging changes are needed to put us on a long-term path towards sustainability and flourishing.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Here you can use your political capital to wrangle support for policies to implement worldwide.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Large-scale projects, like mass electrification or geoengineering schemes, will help the development of a prosperous future.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Here you can spend political capital to marshal resources towards building and sustaining these projects.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: We have a wide array of processes to produce two critical resources: food and energy.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: It's up to regional planners the exact mixes of processes. They'll decide based on on-the-ground conditions like resource scarcity and demand.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: But as a planetary planner you can influence their decisions by banning or promoting certain processes, or by developing new ones through research.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Your plans will benefit from having others on board. Others may come to trust you more or less based on how you make decisions.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: If a person trusts you enough they may be able to help you in unique ways.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: You've survived your first planning cycle!

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: At the end of each cycle you'll be presented a report summarizing changes.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: These numbers will need to improve if you want to keep your position as a planner!

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: A global temperatures rise, extinction rates accelerate, or worldwide contentedness declines, people will lose faith in your abilities.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: And you'll gain political capital as those improve.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: In theory anyone with enough political capital can get anything done, but you're new around here so there won't be much you can do.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: For now you can build some reputation as the human-in-the-loop for our planetary monitoring system.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Disasters and other situations in need of assistance will show up on this globe.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Responding to events by tapping on them in a timely manner will yield you political capital.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Those numbers you're evaluated on in your report are also shown at the top of this screen.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Up there you'll see the current extinction pressure, global contentedness, annual CO2-equivalent emissions, and current global temperature anomaly.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: You've probably also noticed the angry heads emerging when a disaster occur.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: The more frequent and more intense these disasters are, the more people will be unhappy with your performance as a planner.

lines.speaker: Gossy
lines.text: Do what you can to prevent them from happening in the first place!

e54d7e47-31fe-4578-8966-841207c8bd97.name: Algae Biofuels
e54d7e47-31fe-4578-8966-841207c8bd97.notes:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780323852692000022

This assessment of one particular kind of algae biofuel: https://openbiotechnologyjournal.com/VOLUME/12/PAGE/270/FULLTEXT/

> (50.59 MJ/kg) associated with low consumption of water (28.38 m3/kg) and low CO2 emissions (9.18 kg CO2-eq/kg)

This is about 14kWh/kg, so:
- water: 2.03 L/kWh
- CO2: 655.7g CO2eq/kWh

The energy inputs required is 27.21MJ per kg, will just assume that's all electricity -> 7.5583333kWh

That paper doesn't have land use, but this one provides a range: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1364032117301612

From <0.01m2/MJ to around 0.14m2/MJ. Most of the studies are closer to 0.02m2/MJ, so say that, or 0.072m2/kWh
